title: My Skin Was a Mess. Then I Tried This Pear Tallow Balm.
body:
Look. My skin in winter is a disaster. It’s not a cute, dewy, snowflake situation. It’s more like a dry, tight, flaky map of regret. I’m talking about skin that feels like it’s two sizes too small for my face. And my hands? Forget it. They’d crack by the knuckles if I even thought about cold air. I was desperate. I tried that expensive cream in the blue jar everyone talks about. Felt like slick plastic. Tried the drugstore lotion that smells like a chemical flower garden. It burned. I was using this weird gel thing for a while that just sat on top of my skin, shiny and useless, while everything underneath felt like sandpaper. I was at the end of my rope. Or my lotion bottle. Whatever.

Then I kept seeing stuff about tallow balm. Beef fat. For your face. I mean, come on. It sounded like something my great-grandmother would have used before they invented, you know, actual skincare. But I was scrolling Etsy one night, it was late, like 1 AM, and I was just done. I found this shop selling a Whipped Tallow Balm in “Pear” scent. Made in France. From grass-fed cows. The whole thing. I figured, it’s winter, my skin is already a lost cause, how much worse could it get? So I ordered it. A last-ditch, why-not, this-is-probably-gross kind of purchase.

## Why Beef Tallow for Skin? (It Sounds Weird, I Know)

Okay, so I did a tiny bit of reading after I bought it, because I started to panic. What did I just put on my credit card? The science, or whatever, is actually kind of simple. Our skin makes its own oil, right? Sebum. Tallow from grass-fed animals is apparently really close to that. Like, structurally similar. So instead of just sitting on top of your skin like most lotions, it can actually sink in. It’s not a foreign substance your skin freaks out about. It’s more like… a reinforcement. Good for winter damage, they said. Good for psoriasis. Good for chapped lips. My lips were perpetually chapped. I was skeptical but also weirdly hopeful. The whole “mimics human sebum” thing made a dumb kind of sense to my sleep-deprived brain.

It showed up in a little box. I was wearing my rattiest sweatpants. The jar itself was cute, simple. I opened it. Here’s where I expected to be grossed out.

The texture was… not what I thought. I thought it’d be greasy. Like bacon grease. It wasn’t. It was whipped, so it was super light and airy, like cool buttercream frosting but not sweet. You scoop a tiny bit and it melts the second it hits your skin warmth. The smell? They said “subtle sweetness, light and fresh, fruity.” I braced for a fake, overpowering pear candy smell. It wasn’t that. It was soft. Like a real pear, but if the pear was really subtle and sophisticated. Not a scent. Just a… feeling. A fresh feeling. I don’t know how to describe it better than that. It just smelled clean and a tiny bit sweet. Nothing perfumey. Nothing that gave me a headache.

## How I Use This Tallow Stuff (And What Actually Happened)

My routine is not a routine. It’s chaos. But here’s what I did. After I washed my face at night, while my skin was still a little damp, I’d take a dab of this tallow balm about the size of a pea. Rub it between my fingers to warm it up more, then just press it into my skin. On my face. On my knuckles. On my elbows. Anywhere that felt like the Sahara.

The first thing I noticed was that it didn’t just sit there. It absorbed. Like, actually went away. My skin felt… calm. Not greasy. Not shiny. Just normal. But softer. The tight, itchy feeling was gone in like, two minutes. That was night one.

After a few days, the cracks on my knuckles started to look less angry. They were just… there. Not bleeding. My face stopped feeling like it was going to split when I smiled. But the real moment was maybe two weeks in. I was getting ready for bed and I rubbed my cheek absentmindedly. And it was just… smooth. No flakes. No rough patches. Just skin. I hadn’t felt my own skin feel like actual skin in months. Maybe years. I remember just staring at my hand in the bathroom light, turning it over, because my elbows—my eternally crusty, neglected elbows—were, and I swear this is true, smooth. Not perfect. But smooth. Like they’d been sanded down by a very gentle angel.

I started using it on my lips before bed. Just a tiny smear. Woke up and they weren’t stuck together with dried skin. It was wild.

## My Skin Now & Would I Buy It Again?

So it’s been a few months. Winter’s still hanging on, but my skin isn’t fighting me anymore. It’s not a miraculous transformation into a glowing goddess. I still have pores. I still get a random zit. But the baseline state of my skin has fundamentally changed. It’s hydrated. It’s resilient. When I wake up, my face doesn’t feel tight. My hands don’t look like I’ve been fist-fighting sandpaper. I’m on my second jar now. I got one for my mom, who has even drier skin than me, and she texted me last week saying “what is this magic butter?” She calls it magic butter.

I told my sister about it. She was like, “tallow? Really?” And I was like, “look, I know it sounds insane. Just try it.” I sound like a cult member. But I don’t care. When something works this well, after you’ve tried a million things that don’t, you get evangelical about it.

For me, this pear tallow balm was the answer. A natural moisturizer for skin that just drinks up moisture and then spits it back out. The best tallow for that deep, winter-long dryness that makes you miserable. A tallow balm for skin that’s sensitive and reactive and just tired of being slathered in chemicals that don’t work.

If you’re curious, I got mine from this little Etsy shop that makes it. The Whipped Tallow Balm in Pear. It’s not a sponsored thing, I just really like it. It sits on my nightstand next to my water glass and my phone charger. A little jar of beef fat that fixed my face. Life is weird.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, surprisingly. The idea freaked me out too. But since it’s so similar to our skin’s own oils, it absorbs way better than a lot of plant oils or synthetic stuff. It doesn’t just coat your skin—it seems to help it repair itself. My face definitely thinks it’s good.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Hasn’t for me. And I can get clogged pores easy. Because it absorbs so deeply and isn’t just sitting on the surface, it doesn’t seem to block anything up. It’s the opposite—my skin feels like it can finally breathe because it’s not dehydrated and freaking out.

**What does the Pear tallow balm smell like?**
It’s hard to pin down. It’s not a strong, candy pear scent. It’s more like the idea of a fresh pear. Light. A little sweet, but in a clean, gentle way. It’s not perfumey at all. It just smells… nice. And the smell fades pretty quick after you put it on.

Anyway. If your skin is being a difficult, flaky monster this winter, maybe give tallow a shot. I was the biggest skeptic, and now I’m just a person with smooth elbows. Go figure.
